sideA: Ellos no dejaron documentación al respecto.

sideB.text: They didn't leave any documentation regarding this.
They left no documentation about it.
There is no documentation left on this matter.
They didn't leave any documentation about it.
They didn't leave documentation about it.
They left behind no documentation regarding the matter.

note:
[Regarding] is a professional alternative to 'about'.

~Regarding to this~ is incorrect. Never use 'to' after 'regarding'.

sideA: PL/SQL en EBS era mucho más profundo de lo que había visto; solo sabía lo básico de la universidad.

sideB.text: PL/SQL with EBS was way deeper than I'd seen—I only knew basics from school.
The PL/SQL in EBS was much more complex than what I learned in college.
EBS PL/SQL went far beyond the basic knowledge I had from school.
PL/SQL with EBS was much deeper than I thought — I only knew the basics from school.
I was only familiar with the basics from university.

note:
[Way deeper] is a common colloquial way to say 'much more complex/profound'.

~...than I saw...~ (Grammar: Use [than I had seen] (past perfect) to refer to the time before you started working with EBS.)

~...I only knew basics from school.~ (Grammar: You need the definite article 'the' before 'basics'. Correct: 'I only knew the basics'.)

sideA: Las definiciones de los productos (su ADN) y su stock están en tablas distintas.

sideB.text: Product definitions (their DNA) and their stock levels are stored in separate tables.
We separate the item master data from the physical on-hand quantities into different tables.
The Master Item table defines the product, while a different table tracks the physical inventory.
Product definitions (their DNA) and their stock are in different tables.
Product definitions and inventory levels reside in distinct tables.

note:
[Master Data] (definitions) vs [Transactional Data] (stock levels) is a key concept in database design.

[Stored in] is the standard preposition for data in tables.
